bibl.title: Letter from Mahlon Ashford to Albert E. Truby, January 2, 1942

div1.p: Ashford, editor of the "Bulletin of the New York Academy of Medicine," expresses an interest in publishing Truby's book on the yellow fever experiments and informs him that Lazear's missing notebook is not to be found at the Academy library.

div1.head: Letter from Mahlon Ashford to Albert E. Truby, January 2, 1942
div1.opener:
BULLETIN OF
THE NEW YORK ACADEMY OF MEDICINE
2 EAST 103 STREET
NEW YORK
TELEPHONE ATWATER 9-4700
EDITORIAL BOARD
JEROME P. WEBSTER, Chairman
ALFRED E. COHN
EUGENE F. DUBOIS
ROBERT F. LOEB
ARCHIBALD MALLOCH
PHILIP VAN INGEN
KARL VOGEL
MAHLON ASHFORD, Editor
January 2, 1942
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby
div1.p:
On my recent return to the office I found your letter of December 19.
I am very happy to hear from you and very much interested in your
proposal that the Academy publish the book you have written concern-
ing the yellow fever work of Walter Reed.

In the first place, I should advise you that the Academy Library does
not possess the missing laboratory book with Lazear's notes about
mosquito work at Columbia Barracks in 1900. There have been several
reports to the contrary but recently at the request of General Ire-
land I asked the Librarian to search once more and the Librarian in-
forms me definitely that the Library does not possess this notebook.

Regarding your own book, we shall be most happy if you decide to sub-
mit it to us with a view to publication. It has occurred to me that
your account might be suitable for primary publication in the Bulletin
as a serial and subsequent publication in one complete volume. Of
course you understand that I cannot promise publication in book form
until the manuscript has been submitted to the Library Publication Com-
mittee.

I do not know how well acquainted with the Academy Bulletin you are
but I am mailing you a copy of a recent issue.

The Bulletin has a circulation of 4,000 of which total approximately
2,000 copies go to physicians in New York, 1,000 to other States,
and 1,000 to Libraries and foreign subscribers. I think the Bulle-
tin reaches all of the principal medical libraries of the world.
div1.closer:
With kindest regards,
Sincerely yours Mahlon Ashford MA:GJ
